question: Look at the AC input cable feeding power into the device. Check for damage or exposed wires.
Is the cable in good condition?
Carefully open up the device.
Follow the power cord into the device. Use a voltmeter to check the voltage in the device before any circuit components.
Is voltage greater than zero?
If possible, repair the cable (resolder and/or tape). Otherwise, replace the cable.
Test the input voltage to the device when the device power switch is on and off.
Does the switch work properly?  Switch off = 0 Volts, switch on = correct voltage
Does the device use a fuse?
Use a multimeter to check if the fuse shorts.
Does the fuse short?
The fuse is working properly.
The power supply is working. Calibrate and troubleshoot the device before putting it back into service.
Inspect the condition of components in the power supply. Check for puffy capacitors, melted or burnt components, and signs of rust or corrosion.
Do any components need replacing?
Does the device use a bulky internal transformer?
Replace leaking or corroded components with exact replacements. If not, try to use components from old, dysfunctional equipment. Otherwise, replace power supply.
Use a voltmeter in connection mode to check for shorts within components of the power supply.
Were any shorts detected?
Replace shorted components if possible (solder). If not, replace the power supply.
Using a voltmeter, check for DC voltage in each component of the power supply before the small internal transformer.
Is DC voltage present in all components?
Does the power supply turn on?
Replace the power supply.
options: Back to start of power supply troubleshooting

question: Identify the fuse amperage, voltage, and type (should be printed on the fuse or device). If not, make an educated guess by comparing with fuses of known specifications, and use knowledge of the device.
Can a fuse be found with the exact correct specifications?
Replace the fuse.
Replace the fuse with one of as many specification matches as possible. If not, make a temporary replacement fuse.
details: Amperage: Replace with lower amperage NOT higher amperage. Voltage: A higher voltage can replace a lower voltage fuse. A lower voltage fuse CANNOT replace a higher voltage fuse. Type: Fast acting can replace a slow acting fuse. Slow acting CANNOT replace fast acting.

question: Pull out the 3-pin voltage regulator.
Again check for shorts to ground in each component of the power supply.
Are there any shorts to ground?
Replace the voltage regulator.
Use a voltmeter in connection mode to check for shorts within components of the power supply.
Do any connections short to ground?
Replace shorted components if possible (solder). If not, replace the power supply.
Troubleshoot the transformer to make sure it is working properly.
Replace shorted components if possible (solder). If not, replace the power supply.
Repair the switch or replace components.
